direction.raw_text: A young teacher (DARLA) chalks a lesson on a blackboard in a sun-drenched Los Angeles classroom.

direction.raw_text: and we know from yesterday that the base of a triangle times half the height equals the area. A girl in the back row raises her hand.

The girl from the opening scene. LUCY SHERIDAN. Darla stands over her with obvious concern. Puts a finger to her lips to quiet the giggles.

direction.raw_text: He would just go off, you know, start tearin' the place down. You didn't even know why he was doin' it half the time, you just got out of his way...

direction.raw_text: And what you learned from your father now Diego's learning from you...? It's painful for him to hear that. He loves his son, quit the streets for him. Overcome by emotion, he nods yes.

direction.raw_text: That really upsets you, doesn't it? He wipes his eyes on his tattooed arm.

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Cuz I mean I don't want him to be like me. The boy looks at his father, has never seen him cry before.

direction.raw_text: That's the last time I make a bet with you. (to his parents) See you guys next week. The Martinez family heads down the hall, Diego lagging behind. Emily watches with guarded optimism, knowing their chances. Then turns to the NEXT FAMILY, welcoming the

direction.raw_text: The hurried opening and closing of files reveals PHOTOS of abused children. Bruises. Cuts. Broken bones. Emily trying to locate a single case amid the stacks and clutter on her desk. An angry mother SCREAMING at her on the phone:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one is trying to steal your child, they found bruises and cigarette burns -- Mrs Lynch, I read the medical report -- well, if you feel you need legal representation that's perfectly within your rights... A flurry of obscenities followed by a dial tone. Emily puts the phone down. Sighs wearily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) One less Christmas card for Emily. Her supervisor WAYNE, forties, gay, leaning in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many active cases you have?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thirty-eight. He drops another file on her desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, absolutely not, look at this, Wayne, look, I'm buried -- WAYNE Sorry, Em, we all are. He walks off. Emily shoves the new file onto the shelf above her desk. Looks at it guiltily. Takes it down again. Handwritten on the front: SHERIDAN, LUCY. She opens it. A school portrait of ten-year-old Lucy clipped to the preliminary report. The sad face draws Emily in.

direction.raw_text: Emily leans on an elbow as she drives, not crazy about L.A. but at ease with herself.

direction.raw_text: Emily's red Volvo wagon turns in the drive of a single-person home she rents in a working-class neighborhood.

direction.raw_text: Cozy. Her haven. Light colors offset dark hardwood floors. Emily comes in, stack of files under her arm. Tired. Long day. Drops the files in a chair. Sprinkles some food in a fish tank. Referees through the glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't fight. Hey, that's his. Turns on the tv. World news. Violence. People suffering. Turns it off. Puts on some quiet music. Hits play on her answering machine as she flops down barefoot on the sofa with a magazine, peeling an orange, decompressing.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exhausted, her career path questionable, her faith in mankind shaken, she resisted her tendency toward introspection and went to have a drink with her friend Doug.

direction.raw_text: . Emily gives a tired sigh. Faint smile under it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Noisy, trendy downtown bar. Professional type on a bar stool. Thirties. Handsome. DOUG. He laughs when he sees Emily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am so in your head. She gives him a kiss. Sits down beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be honest. The whole psychology thing, it's just about scoring chicks, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Regrettably, yes. They share a laugh. He gestures to the bartender for another beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what freaks me out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That you have a four-year degree and make seventeen grand a year after taxes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sit there talking to these families, you know, like I'm some expert. My family's a train wreck. I mean, I had this moment today where I realized I might be totally full of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody's full of it. In the end you're a number to call for people who don't have anyone else. There's no way that's bad. Emily nods, appreciates that. Recognizes a girl going by in the crowd. A friend from school. Well-dressed. Career- oriented. The track Emily might be on if she weren't a social worker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Becca...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey. So one of us is a major screwup, I can't remember if I was supposed to call you or the other way around...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's me, it's just been a crazy couple weeks. You remember Doug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. (then to Emily) Listen, my ride's leaving, let's catch up soon, okay? Emily nods okay. The girl departs. Emily's beer arrives. Doug hands it to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So anyway, I've done some soul searching and I just want to say that if a full-on relationship feels like too much right now, I'd be willing to consider a purely physical one. Emily, sipping her beer, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, you might actually enjoy yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure I would, I just... Hard to explain. Doug saves her the trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, I know, the job, you get home you don't have anything left. Emily nods yeah, leans in closer, the friendly banter giving way to a moment of real sincerity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it were anyone, it'd be you. They exchange a look then Doug clinks his glass against hers. And as they drink together after a long day, more than friends, less than lovers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily in glasses, reading the Sheridan file on her bed. The preliminary report concerns her: "Socially withdrawn. Lack of appetite. Sleeping at school..." Her gaze returns to Lucy's photo. Sadly, under her breath:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are they doing to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A dark, rundown family home on a once-prosperous cul de sac. Emily pulls up. Gets out. Checks that she has the right address. Halfway up the walk something stops her dead in her
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: staring at her through one of the lacy white curtains upstairs. Ghostly pale. Gone as soon as she sees it. Emily stands frozen for a moment. Walks on. She reaches to knock on the door and it opens abruptly, the security chain snapping taut. A woman's voice growls at her from the darkness inside:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily Jennings. Child Services? We spoke on the phone...? Peering through the crack is the pallid, bony face from the upstairs window. Lucy's mother. MARGARET SHERIDAN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said the seventeenth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Today is the seventeenth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, but it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Friday was the thirteenth. Emily, rather amazed at the conversation she's having, takes a newspaper from her bag. Indicates the date.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Friday was the fourteenth, that makes today the seventeenth. Monday the seventeenth. The date of our appointment. The door closes in Emily's face. What the hell? Then we hear the chain unlock. It opens again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . And we get our first good look at Lucy's mother. Gaunt. Pale. Dark rings under her eyes. She steps aside, not welcoming Emily in, merely allowing her to enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's dark, the curtains drawn. Margaret twitches one open in begrudging courtesy. The house is tidy but sad, steeped in a kind of puritanical gloom. Lucy peers down through the upstairs banister, anxious, unsure what's going on. Emily sees her, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come down, I'd like to meet you. Lucy hesitates, sensing her mother's disapproval. Comes slowly down the stairs. Emily shakes her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name's Emily. What's yours?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pretty name. Pretty girl. Lucy turns shyly away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there somewhere we can talk? Margaret sighs and heads down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily, file in hand, trying to project professionalism in an arm chair that tilts to one side. Margaret and Lucy sitting opposite on the sofa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When do you expect your husband back? Margaret shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because we've found it's more beneficial if the whole family participates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well he's not home so... Shrugs again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have any way of contacting him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not if I don't know where he is. Just then we hear a POWER TOOL go on in the basement. Emily, sensing the lie, indicates the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that...? Margaret averts her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you ask him to join us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't have anything to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you ask him? Margaret weighs Emily's resolve, gives Lucy a cautionary glance then exits. We hear her open a door and holler into the basement over the noise of the power tool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Edward! EDWARD! The power tool stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) That lady's here. From the state. She wants to talk to you. We hear an angry unintelligible reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) I already told her, she wants to anyway. We hear the power tool get thrown aside. FOOTSTEPS pounding up the cellar stairs. Emily's and Lucy's faces reflect the same simple fear. Their eyes meet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll be okay. Lucy not so sure. The FOOTSTEPS are upon them. EDWARD SHERIDAN makes his entrance. A menacing man with a gaunt face and dark deep-set eyes. Emily holds out her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, I'm Emily -- Edward forgoes the handshake, his contempt obvious. Sits beside Lucy on the sofa. Margaret sits on the other side. Lucy tenses, trapped between them. Emily speaks with kindness and composure. Hostile encounters part of the job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here today because Lucy's school is concerned about changes they're seeing in her academic performance. The kinds of changes they're seeing are often associated with family problems. Edward leans over and whispers something caustic in Margaret's ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eddie says we don't have family problems.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's just it, many times a family won't even know they're having problems until it's too late. That's where we come in. We help families communicate and learn healthier ways of resolving conflict. Edward whispers again in Margaret's ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eddie says we don't need your help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Sheridan, is there some reason you won't speak to me directly? Edward just stares at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there some reason why your husband won't speak to me directly? Margaret nods, gives Edward a look as though for permission.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eddie doesn't like speakin' out of anger. Emily does well to hide her fear. Refusing to be intimidated, she engages Edward's stare. A battle of wills. But his gaze has a murderous intensity she can't match. She looks down, shuffling papers. Battle lost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily follows Wayne along a row of cubicles after hours. He's dropping files on desks. The new cases never stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No laws against being weird, Em. Send it over to CMC, we'll do a follow-up in a month.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't say weird, I said scary. The guy sat there the entire time staring at me, the mother is like his emotional slave. Wayne pauses in mock bewilderment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait, did you just fly to New York and meet my parents?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wayne, this girl's in trouble. I can feel it. Beneath Wayne's humor, a sober, hard-learned practicality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wanna know what I can feel? The lawsuit we're gonna get hit with if we violate her parents' rights without any evidence they've done something wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every time I talk to you you sound more like a lawyer, you know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well, maybe because every time I make an emotional decision I get called by one. I'm sorry, you're gonna have to let this one go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You put these files in front of me and you ask me to tell you what's going on. Well, I'm telling you, there's something going on and it's not something good. I've done my job, I've told you, what you do with it is yours. She walks off. Wayne alone after hours with his conscience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The elevator doors open with a DING and Edward and Margaret Sheridan step out in their Sunday best. Benevolent faces. Lucy between them, ribbon in her hair, brand new dress, appearing coached as she eats an ice cream cone. Emily, disgusted by the charade, trades looks with the parents as they go past.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gazing fondly at Lucy, Edward directs his comments at Wayne, who sits opposite the family with Emily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They really are God's miracles. Day she was born was the happiest day of our lives. We're not perfect parents, we know that, but we figure if you let `em know how much you love `em a lot of the other stuff takes care of itself. Wayne nods his agreement. Edward puts his arm around Lucy for effect. Her eyes go to Emily. A silent plea for help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me, Mr Sheridan, since you've suddenly acquired the power of speech, doesn't it concern you a little that Lucy's grades have gone from A's to D's in three months?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Course it does, she's our daughter. With a glance Wayne cautions Emily about her tone of voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you have no idea why she's falling asleep at school every day? Why she's not able to sleep at home? Edward looks at Margaret, then Emily, affects bewilderment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bad dreams?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily and Wayne in private conversation. She's pissed off. The Sheridan family in the other room, preparing to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's gonna be having bad dreams when he gets hit with child endangerment. (off Wayne's reluctance) Don't tell me you're buying this daddy's little girl routine?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So they're overcompensating a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little? Let me talk to her. Alone. She wants to talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five minutes. Talk to them about how much they love kids. She goes out the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily walks with Lucy, looking for a way in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew someone at school named Lucy, she was a writer. Do you ever write? I do sometimes, it helps me sort out how I'm feeling. Lucy doesn't take the bait. She stops for a drink at a water fountain. Emily bends for a sip after. Misfires. As she wipes her face, embarrassed:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, I just shot like a gallon of water up my nose. So much for establishing trust. Lucy smiles, for the first time. It's the opening Emily was looking for. Maintaining that precious eye contact,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's happening to you? I can help. Let me help. Lucy looks away, eyes brimming with tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it, sweetheart?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They hate me. She lowers her head in shame, tears rolling down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure they don't hate you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They do. I hear them. They go in the cellar and talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do they talk about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sending me to hell. Emily's mouth falls open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've heard them say that? Lucy nods. As Emily registers this in quiet horror...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tape recorder is running. Emily and Wayne alone with Lucy. She's hesitant to speak, naturally distrustful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay. You can tell him. He's on our side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you hear your parents say they were going to hurt you? Nobody sees what Lucy sees at this moment. Edward glaring in at her through the window. Lucy looks at Wayne, shakes her head. Wayne looks at Emily, case closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily watches in agony as the Sheridan family steps into the elevator. Parent on each side, Lucy gives her one last pleading look then the elevator doors close and she's gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily and Wayne in the heat of an argument.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't trust anybody. You think I made it up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you'd do just about anything you had to do to help a child you thought was at risk. Here are the facts, Emily. They haven't laid a finger on her that we can tell. And we have no proof they intend to. Meanwhile on your desk right now are thirty-plus cases of actionable abuse. What about those?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not giving up on her, Wayne.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, you are, you're leaving this alone. A look that says he means it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you can live with a dead child on your conscience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a little unfair, don't you think? I care about these kids as much as you do, but we can't go around yanking them out of their homes on a hunch. Parents, even bad ones, have rights, that's how the laws of this great land are written. Emily gives a resigned nod, backing away from him, from the job, all of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So that's it? We let kids get killed until they rewrite the goddamn laws? She exits before he can answer, doesn't want to hear it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Detective MIKE BARRON. Veteran of the force. Man of quiet faith.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A well-built silver-haired family man who played fullback at Brigham Young. He's doing paperwork. Smiles warmly as Emily enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was just thinking about you, got a nice letter from Sandy Hutchinson... She drops Lucy's file on his desk. Whatever Barron was going to say is no longer relevant. Soberly, after a pause:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's sitting in front of me which means our good friend Wayne thinks it fails to meet the criteria for child endangerment and has told you in no uncertain terms to leave it alone...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Surprise, surprise. She starts to open the file. Barron stops her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't, Emily. I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike, I'm desperate here. Tense beat. The need for privacy now apparent, Barron gets up and closes his door. Sits down at his desk again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know how dear to my heart the work you do is, but the department doesn't pay me to stakeout potential child abusers. Last time almost cost me my job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This girl heard her parents say they're going to send her to hell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sickening as that is, you're a part of the system that handles those situations, I'm not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The system is broken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you just need to let it work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Jesus, I feel like I'm talking to Wayne. You don't want to get involved, fine, but don't bullshit me, I'm running out of people I respect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. No bullshit. Give me evidence of a crime, I'll be all over it. Till then there's nothing I can do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The blade of a circular saw SCREAMS through a pinewood board, spitting sawdust... A ten-pound hammer CRUSHES the head of a nail, sinking it,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: another, CRUSHES another, the speed of the handiwork conveying its urgency...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucy peering into the basement through an air vent in the floor, vertical bands of light on her face. Edward hammering down below. He steps aside and we see what he's making...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sensing Lucy's stare, he glances up over his shoulder. And Lucy ducks out of sight, breath held.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Children waiting for the bus after school. Talking, laughing. Lucy stands apart, tired and solemn. The bus pulls up to the curb. As she goes to get on:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Lucy. She turns. Emily behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just wanted you to know I haven't forgotten about you. I'm doing everything I can. Lucy hugs her, clinging for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I disappear will you come look for me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not going to disappear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I do? Emily holds her gaze, seeing the fear. Backing away, Lucy indicates the bus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to go. They get mad when I miss the bus. Lucy turns to go. Emily watches. Helpless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucy, wait... Takes her cell phone from her bag. Puts her number on speed dial.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If anything happens, call me, okay? Just press this. Don't let your parents know you have it. Tucks the cell phone in Lucy's coat pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm gonna get you out of there, I promise. Lucy boards the bus. Waves to Emily from a back window as it drives away. Emily waves back, heart in her throat. Might be the last time she sees her alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A sleepless night finds Emily slouched on her sofa, leaving a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, this is Doug, here it comes -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's me, thought you might be up, um, anyway, call if you get this. Hangs up. Clicks on the tv remote. Channel-surfs. World news. Cooking show. Home shopping network.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Hip-hop music video. Watches it for a moment. Gangster with a mic. Scantily-clad girls shaking their asses. The phone RINGS. Emily mutes the tv, picks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too late, I met someone else... A child's whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Emily...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (concerned but calm) Lucy? Are you okay?

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I'm scared...

direction.raw_text: Why? Why are you scared, honey?

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) They're waiting to get me, I can hear them... I'm sorry...

direction.raw_text: Why are you sorry?

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I'm falling asleep...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, listen, I want you to go over and open the window. Can you do that? Lucy...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) (softly; drifting off) I'm sooorry...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucy, no, wake up!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cell phone lying on the bed at Lucy's fingertips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucy...?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The illuminated screen casts an eerie glow on her SLEEPING FACE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily drops the phone. Moment of panic. Then a decision. Throws a coat on over her bed clothes. Grabs the phone again, dials a number in desperation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike, it's Emily, listen, that girl I told you about, I think she's in trouble - - yeah, I know what you said, but -- Mike, you're not listening -- (LOSES IT) HELP ME!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily fumbles with her keys. Gets the right one in the door. Opens it. Jumps in. Starts the engine. Peels off down the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cell phone turns itself off, plunging the room into total darkness. In BLACK, we hear FOOTSTEPS coming up the stairs. Down the hall. Stopping at the door. The knob turning. The click of the latch. The door opening. A shaft of light. Edward and Margaret peering in with frenzied anticipation: Lucy is asleep. The time has come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily red-lines the tachometer, doing ninety down the freeway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slowly, quietly, Edward descends the stairs with Lucy asleep in his arms. Margaret in front of him, moving in tandem, holding a roll of duct tape. They reach the bottom. Margaret rushes ahead into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward carries Lucy toward the OLD GAS OVEN where Margaret waits, holding open the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Delicately, cradling her head, Edward puts Lucy into the oven without waking her. But as he lifts the door, one of the metal hinges CREAKS. Lucy jolts awake with a SCREAM. Kicks open the door before Edward can shut it. With animal terror she thrashes her way out onto the linoleum floor. Margaret throws a piece of duct tape over her mouth, silencing her screams as Edward wrestles her back into the oven. But she kicks open the door again and the frantic struggle continues as...
direction.name: direction

She picks it up and it GOES OFF in her hand. Gives her a scare. She puts it down. Sees something out the bedroom window. Steps closer. Parts the curtains. In the backyard, by the garden shed, a long rectangular hole has been dug. A SHALLOW GRAVE filling with leaves. Edward's handiwork. Emily's seen enough, heads for the door. But slows, noticing something odd as she comes back around the bed -

Emily and her mother sitting on the steps of a house, together but apart, like a lost child that sat down next to a pretty stranger who hasn't yet noticed her. Emily's ten-year-old face shows the quiet sadness of the disconnect. Reminds you of a child from her caseload.

direction.raw_text: She used to just leave, she'd just... (GESTURES `ADIOS') ...and I never knew when she was coming back, or if she was... I used to think it was my fault and I would try so hard when she got home to be good, do everything I could think of, so she'd think I was `special' and stay next time or take me with her, but... it didn't matter, she'd always go away again, that's how it was. Emily fights her emotions and, practiced at the task, wins. Lucy sits beside her on the bed. Understands her deeply. Linked by their pasts.

Its little legs twitching. Drops it in. Flushes. A false respite. And a brief one. Because as the FLUSHING NOISE FADES he can hear an ominous DEEP BUZZING SOUND RISING. It's coming from behind him. He turns to have a look. Nothing there. Bare wall. But it's strange: the BUZZING IS STILL BEHIND HIM. With dawning horror Doug turns and checks his back in the mirror, sees

Holding it by the collar, he takes two quick steps and tosses it in the shower. Slams the glass door, seals the crack with towels. And watches the hornets fly around in the glass enclosure, BUZZING FURIOUSLY, bouncing off the glass. But as he backpedals he realizes the FURIOUS BUZZING is too close, too loud and too deep, to be coming from the shower over there. A sharp pain in his head confirms it. He GROANS and brings a hand to his ear as something awful happens inside. The BUZZING in his right ear spreads to his left - LOUDER, ANGRIER, its sources multiplying. Disoriented, he stumbles backwards with an AGONIZING SCREAM. Catches sight of himself in the mirror, the terror of the moment on his face. This can't be happening. And now the nightmare takes a devilish turn. Looking at himself in the mirror, he sees -

Doug grabs his head in both hands and starts shaking it, trying to shake away the madness inside. But the hornets keep coming, COUGHED UP IN CLUMPS as he gasps for air. They're all over him, stinging his tongue, his eyes. He goes berserk and starts SMASHING HIS HEAD against the wall, the door, the edge of the sink, anything he can find, opening a deep gash in his forehead, smashing it harder and harder because the BUZZING WON'T STOP, cracking his skull,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pitching his head violently forwards and backwards like some demon-possessed heavy metal fanatic. It's a grotesque display that ends on a sickening note when, with one particularly violent head jerk, he snaps his own neck - CRACK!!! He sinks to the floor, head askew, astonished look on his face. And there he sits, paralyzed, eyes locked on the tv in the living room where football highlights play in silence. Fully conscious as the hornets fight their way back into his ears, nose, and mouth - a pilgrimage back to the mind that bore them.
